title: Why (and when) deferring taxes is not your best option

author.name: Amanda Lott
author.title: Head of Wealth Planning & Innovation, Advice Lab

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Contrary to the common assumption, deferring taxes is not always a good idea. We caution against what many people routinely do: automatically opt for tax-deferred accounts. They usually do so because they assume their ordinary income tax rate will be lower after they retire. Or they think: “Even if my tax rate won’t be lower, it’s better to put it off for as long as possible.” They can be wrong on both points.

sections.title: Potential Tax Rates in Retirement
sections.content: People are often surprised to find they are still subject to top U.S. tax rates when they no longer draw a high salary but have significant assets. Also, and critically: Very few people realize that financial outcomes can be significantly different when you put pre-tax versus after-tax dollars into tax-deferred accounts.

numbers.description: Current top federal tax bracket for annual income of about $731,200 for a couple and $609,350 for an individual
Top federal tax rate scheduled to revert to in 2026

sections.title: Examples of High Income in Retirement
sections.content: Say you have a $30 million portfolio that generates an annual yield of just 2%. That would produce $600,000 of income a year before any capital gains you might realize through rebalancing and prudent portfolio management.

sections.title: When to Choose Taxable Accounts
sections.content: You may want to pay taxes as you go, keeping after-tax dollars in taxable accounts if: You can get preferential tax treatment on their return—i.e., you can pay the 23.8% tax rate for long-term-capital gains (LTCG) or qualified dividend income (QDI).

numbers.description: Preferential tax rate for long-term capital gains or qualified dividend income

sections.title: Making the Right Choice
sections.content: What happens when you put a so-called “tax-efficient investment” into a tax-deferred account? Instead of paying 23.8% along the way, you’d pay nearly double in taxes on the funds—37%—when you finally make withdrawals.

sections.title: When Tax Deferral Makes Sense
sections.content: There are five main reasons to put your after-tax dollars into tax-deferred accounts. Investments are “tax-inefficient” (i.e., their return does not qualify for the 23.8% tax rate as LTCG or QDI).

disclosures: In 2024, the maximum amount of pre-tax dollars you can put into a 401(k) is $23,000 generally with, if you are over 50 years old, another $7,500 allowed (so $30,500).

If an individual is covered by an employer retirement plan, no deduction is allowed for a contribution to a traditional IRA if Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) is above modest thresholds $87,000 for single or head of household taxpayer, and $143,000 for those married and filing jointly).

RMD calculation approximated assuming roughly 4% of the account balance ($80,000 per person in the above example with each having a $2 million IRA account). Based on an individual’s age, the percentage distribution required ranges from ~3.7% at age 73 to ~8.2% at age 90. In 2024, maximum Social Security benefit at full retirement age is $45,864 annually and could be higher if an individual delays until age 70.
Includes the 3.8% Medicare surtax on net investment income.

In contrast, tax-deferred accounts always pass on an embedded tax liability in the form of “income in respect of a decedent” (i.e., the untaxed income that a decedent had earned or had a right to receive during their lifetime). IRD is taxed to the individual beneficiary or entity that inherits this income.
Distributions from a Roth IRA are considered qualified distributions if you are 59½ or older, and the account is at least five years old. Qualified distributions are tax- and penalty-free.
